Startup Takes Aim at Computer-Security Holes
Synack deploys freelance hackers to uncover software flaws; find a bug, claim a bounty For four years, Jay Kaplan helped the National Security Agency find holes in targets' computers so spies could take a peek. Now, he pays freelance hackers to find similar holes so his corporate customers can patch them.
Security Startup Synack Lands $7.5 Million Series A Round
Security Startup Synack Lands $7.5 Million Series A Round
As companies migrate their computing infrastructure to the cloud, a whole new batch of security concerns arise. About 21% of children in the United States live in poverty, and as such, often don't get to chose their education. Millions of Americans lack critical knowledge and skills to fill jobs within growing sectors of our economy. Women make up over half of our population, yet still play a relatively tiny role in rapidly growing science, technology, engineering, and math companies. Newly diagnosed patients with disabling and deadly diseases lack receive limited access to information and experiences, especially from those that have won their battle to survive. These people are all around us. They are our friends, family, and fellow citizens.

Our goal is simple: BRIDGE THE KNOWLEDGE GAP among the disadvantaged, unfortunate, and overlooked so they can make the world a better place for themselves and us.

Going from 0 to 1, as a technical co-founder we built a voice and video over IP consumer app on the desktop and mobile phones. Gizmo5's largest direct competitors at that time was Skype (founded on a similar timeline) and the mobile app we created was first launched for Nokia's Symbian OS (with features similar to iMessage on iOS today) and distributed through Nokia's nascent app-store ecosystem. The Nokia mobile app effort eventually failed due to telco opposition to voip and Nokia pulling the app from its store. Gizmo5 was in the end acquired by Google and its tech stack and users absorbed in to Google Voice (GrandCentral)
Exclusive: Google Has Acquired Gizmo5
Exclusive: Google Has Acquired Gizmo5
Last month Skype was in talks to acquire VoIP startup Gizmo5. It was a perfect backup plan in case all that IP litigation didn't work out. - Gizmo5's SIP infrastructure could theoretically replace Skype's proprietary P2P back end.
